awd_abstract_narration:
Staggering volumes of data sets collected by modern applications from financial transaction systems, smart health sensors,  and Internet of Things devices contain critical insights from rare phenomena to anomalies indicative of financial fraud, health alerts to system failure, respectively. To decipher the valuables from the counterfeit, analysts need to interactively sift through and explore the data deluge. By discovering anomalies, analysts may detect financial fraud,  identify  behavior irregularities,  or prevent catastrophic sensor failures, thus touching  the lives of citizens in countless ways. While a treasure trove of stand-alone algorithms for detecting particular types of outliers exists, they tend to be variations on a theme.   This research project is game-changing in that it will offer the first end-to-end outlier services that bring this wealth of algorithms to bear in an integrated infrastructure to support effective anomaly discovery. The broader impact of this project also includes: the integration of the PI's project activities with the training of a STEM workforce; impacting the PI's WPI REU data science summer site; and impacting the new interdisciplinary degree programs from PhD, MS to BS in Data Science spearheaded and led by the PI. The PI has a long history of working with diverse student populations at all levels and is determined to similarly foster diversity of the participants involved in this project.

This research will go well beyond developing yet another outlier detection algorithm by instead demonstrating the feasibility of outlier discovery as a service.  It will break fundamentally new ground in supporting outlier discovery from identification, refinement to explanation. The  proposed  end-to-end anomaly discovery paradigm will support all stages of anomaly discovery by seamlessly integrating outlier-related services within one integrated platform. The result is a database-system inspired solution that models services as first class citizens for the discovery of outliers. It integrates outlier detection processes with data sub-spacing, explanations of outliers with respect to their context in the original data set, user feedback on the relevance of outlier candidates in the domain, and metric-learning to refine the effectiveness of the outlier detection process.  Evaluation using outlier benchmark data sets and real-world data sets and workloads explored in partnerships with collaborators from industry will be conducted to establish the utility of the innovation. The resulting system will enable the analyst to steer the discovery process with human ingenuity, empowered by near real-time interactive responsiveness of the platform during exploration. Our solution aims to be the first to achieve the power of sense-making afforded by outlier explanation services and human feedback integrated into the discovery process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes of this project in terms of intellectual merits and broader impact include:


This project introduced the first continuously adaptive similarity search strategy OASIS. By combining an incremental distance metric learning approach with an efficient dynamic index update strategy, OASIS balances the competing demands of adaptivity and efficiency for outlier detection. OASIS enhances the accuracy of similarity search-based data analysis for outlier detection while delivering a speedup of up to 3 orders of magnitude compared to state-of-the-art methods. OASIS was published in a premier conference, and the code has been released on GitHub.

This project also innovated a semi-supervised method ELITE that, leveraging a small number of labeled samples, improved the performance of outlier detection models compared to the fully unsupervised case. ELITE uses this precious small labeled set as validation data in a meta-gradient-based approach (instead of the traditional training set usage), allowing ELITE to infer the labels of the polluted training data. ELITE is shown to be effective with only very few labeled samples, even when applied to heavily polluted training data. ELITE was published in a premier conference, and the code has been released publicly on GitHub.

Another intellectual merit is AutoOD, the first self-tuning anomaly detection system that automates time-consuming tasks from method selection to hyper-parameter tuning without requiring any human-generated data labels.  Innovations of AutoOD include effective techniques for automatically identifying high likelihood inliers and outliers by leveraging training signals from deep learning models. AutoOD has been shown to be highly effective across countless anomaly benchmark datasets compared to the best unsupervised method.  AutoOD system was published in a premier conference. All code has been released on GitHub to the community.

To democratize outlier detection, this project built and deployed an easy-to-use interactive dashboard for AutoOD. This interface empowers users to visualize, analyze, and understand their data and build trust in the recommendations AutoOD makes. Given different contexts of outliers across applications, this tool incorporates an easy-to-use human-in-the-loop component. This allows users to apply their domain knowledge to further improve AutoOD’s outlier detection performance without requiring extensive machine learning knowledge. This work was published in a premier conference, and has been released  on GitHub.

As outliers are rare and therefore expensive to label, we also designed a new outlier detection method, UNITY, that learns from cheaply generated pseudo-labels generated by unsupervised methods that may contain mistakes, i.e., they are noisy. UNITY is the first learning-from-noisy labels approach for anomaly detection that combines the merits of sample selection and label correction strategies. UNITY employs a pair of deep anomaly models to produce outlier-centric metrics to estimate the likelihood of a sample having a clean label. UNITY leverages the likely clean samples to learn a new embedding space that boosts our ability for the identification and correction of mislabeled samples. UNITY outperforms state-of-the-art learning from noisy techniques across numerous anomaly detection benchmark datasets.

Broader impact includes the integration of this project's activities with the training of a future STEM workforce. Students at all educational levels from BS, MS to Ph.D. students, including several Women+ students, have pursued their research on this NSF project in outlier analytics. With Women and underrepresented students a minority in Data/Computer Sciences, this contributes to the diversity in talent development essential to the prosperity of the US.  These students participated in professional development sessions to hone their communication and presentation skills while pitching their project and its impact to diverse stakeholders, including at the annual WPI Graduate Research Innovation Exchange Day and to the bi-annual Data Science Executive Advisory Board meetings.

Students participating in this NSF project have served as ambassadors and organizers of the Women in Data Science Central Massachusetts @ WPI event, with WIDS a worldwide event held concurrently at 100+ sites across the country and even the world. At WPI, this annual student-run symposium gives our students an opportunity to develop leadership skills, invite speakers and run the sessions. This networking symposium not only provides opportunities to Women+ students to learn about inspiring career opportunities from Women leaders in industry and academia, but they also develop a support network of like-minded Women that will support each other to become part of the talent pool critical for our digital information economy.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2024
Modified by: Elke A Rundensteiner
